description.narrative: Den Internationella Kommissionen mot Straffrihet i Guatemala, CICIG, etablerades efter en vädjan från Guatemala till FN om stöd i kampen mot straffrihet.
The International Commission against Impunity in Guatemala (CICIG), was established upon request by Guatemala to the UN for support in the fight against impunity.

The International Commission against Impunity in Guatemala (CICIG) was established in 2007 as an independent, international body designed to support the Attorney General's Office (MP), the National Civil Police (PNC) and other state institutions in the investigation and prosecution of illicit security forces and clandestine security organizations (CIACS). The mandate was was extended every two years, until the decision in 2019 by the Guatemalan government not to extend it, and the CICIG had to close in September 2019. The mandate was comprised of three main objectives: - to investigate the existence of CIACS that commit crimes that affect the fundamental human rights of the citizens of Guatemala, and identify the structures of these illegal groups (including the links between such groups and state officials) as well as their activities, operating modalities and sources of financin. - to assist the state to disband CIACS, and promote the investigation, criminal prosecution and punishment of the crimes committed by the members of such groups. - to make recommendations to the State of Guatemala regarding public policies to be adopted—including the necessary judicial and institutional reforms—to eradicate and prevent the re-emergence of CIACS.

description.narrative: The International Commission against Impunity in Guatemala (CICIG) was a unique mechanism, created after an agreement between the Guatemalan government and the UN, with the objective to strengthen the rule of law and the justice system in Guatemala. During its twelve years of existence, 2007-2012, CICIG worked closely with state institutions, strengthening their capacity to investigate and prosecute criminal networks, and to suggest legal reforms to improve national legislation and judicial independence. The results of the work were extensive and far reaching with a real and long term impact on the work against impunity and corruption in Guatemala. CICIG, together with the MP, investigated and prosecuted over 70 complex criminal structures, more than 120 high impact cases were brought to court, and closer to 700 people indicted. According to International Crisis Group, CICIG's work on justice reform contributed to a 5 % annual decrease in Guatemala's homicide rate and a fourfold increase in convictions. In total CICIG presented 34 proposals with the aim to increase judicial independence and make legislation more efficient to combat impunity. The work to strengthen capacity of state institutions, including offering state of the art techniques and expertise in establishing competent and specialized structures, resulted in more efficient and focused work, especially at the MP, but other entities such as the Supreme Electoral Tribunal, and the National Police, have benefited from CICIGs expertise. CICIG gained wide recognition and trust among the Guatemalan population, according to polls public trust in CICIG was higher than that of any state institution.
